H0.text: The drops form fog when they become too heavy to float in the air.

H1.text: The drops evaporate when they become too heavy to float in the air during cloud formation, after tiny water droplets that are light enough to float coalesce into larger drops.

H2.text: The drops fall as rain when they become too heavy to float in the air, after forming in clouds from tiny water droplets that collide to create larger drops.

H3.text: The drops become air when they become too heavy to float in the air, concluding the cloudâ€‘formation process that starts with tiny, buoyant water droplets that coalesce into larger droplets.

A4.text: As these larger water droplets descend, coalescence continues, so that drops become heavy enough to overcome air resistance and fall as rain.
